awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Monolayer Devices: A Simulation Study
awd_abstract_narration:
Monolayer materials are two-dimensional sheets of a single atomic layer. Recent experimental demonstration of electronic devices based on various monolayer materials, both from academia and industry, show that the promise of these devices to augment or in some cases replace CMOS based logic systems may soon become a reality. This necessitates that appropriate design tools are available so that individual device behavior observed in experimental labs can be assessed from both a fundamental and also a system point of view. The major intellectual contribution of the efforts proposed in this proposal will be to develop a design software for monolayer devices that is based on fundamental physics yet will exploit the increasing computational capability made available through multi-core architecture and super computing clusters for real time and realistically sized device simulation. The general software will be an integrated tool that describes electron and spin transport in monolayer devices in presence of dissipation mechanisms within a full quantum description and also extend those numerical results to compact models appropriate for circuit and system level simulation. This work will thus, on one hand, advance the fundamental understanding of electronic and spin transport in monolayer 2D materials and on the other, make it possible to take those insights to circuit and system level, thereby fostering disruptive innovation in design and optimization with these emerging materials. 


As the Si based CMOS technology runs its course, new materials with novel functionalities will be necessary to continue the growth of electronics that contributes significantly to the US economy and also to ensure US leadership in computing technologies. New materials may also lower the energy necessary to run computers. Energy dissipation in computers accounts for a few percent of the national energy needs in the US and this percentage is projected to go up as the use of Cloud technology becomes increasingly commonplace in our daily life. This proposal will train graduate students to think about these issues and also encourage them to look for potential solutions. This work will draw on electrical engineering, material science, computational science and physics, thus providing a true interdisciplinary research experience for the students. A number of UC-Berkeley-run programs will be leveraged to include undergraduate researchers specifically focusing on minority and women. Simulation modules will be made available on line to encourage and foster research in new materials for electronic devices. In addition, industrial collaborations will be leveraged for critical feedback and also to provide a channel for commercialization of any relevant technology developed in this research.

por.por_cntn:
The project started in 2011 with the objective to develop a simulation platform for the then novel familty of semiconductor materials which were two dimensional. The two dimensional materials showed significant potential as an alternate channel material to silicon for today's computers. Due to their natural thickness of just one atomic layer, it is possible, in principle, to control their electron density with an electric field highly effectiely. The goal of this project was to assess their potential for efficient device operation for use in digital computers as well as explote novel phenomenal that could emerge in these material systems.

Two graudate students were partially funded by this project and they completed their PhDs within the duration of this project. Varun Mishra investigated the device behavior starting from the question as to how much ON to OFF ratio is actually achivable in transistors using two dimensional material as a device channel. Multiple papers were published from this study that investigated atomistic bandstructure, dependencies on the number of atomic layers and contact resistance. Within this work, another graduate student Zhongyuan Lu was supported for a project where he experimentally chanracterized the interface defect densities in a transistor using MoS2 as a channel material. It was found that, while the atomic thickness is indeed an attractive feature for effective electric field control, the number of defect states in these transistors is significantly high and ultimately determines what kind of control can be achieved. Towards the end of the project Varun Mishra extended his work to spin transport. He showed that it is possible to achieve a one dimensional spin polarized channel, simply by constructing a lateral junction between two dimensional materials, without the need for any external magnetic field. This remarkable finding alludes to the unconventional physics that could be found in these two dimensional material systems, which in turn could lead to device schemes yet unforeseen. Varun Mishra graudated with his PhD and currently working at Intel. Zhongyual Lu graduated with his PhD and is currently working for Micron Technologies.

Towards the end of the project, Samuel Smith was supported under this project to look into graphene nanoribbons which are carbon sheets with a thickness of one atomic layer that are patterened into narrow ribbons. This work was motivated by recent discovery that such 'patterning into narrow ribbons' could be done chemically with perfect edges (no defects). In his study, Samuel Smith showed that these nanoribbons could be used to potentially obtain negative differential resistance where the current decreases for a certain range of increasing voltage. Such negative differential resistance based devices could have many application areas and are currently used in various space related technologies. What is remarkable about Smith's work is the fact that he showed that, using these nanoribbons, it is possible to achieve negative differential resistance in a homogenous device, rather than having to use a heterostructure, which is the conventional practice. Samuel Smith graduated with a PhD and is currently working for Intel corporation.

In addition to producing resarch publications, some part of the the code development led to transfer of a simulation tool to a major semiconductor industry. Moreover, more than 7 unerdgraduate students have participated in the research within the course of this project.
